facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 10, 1962 of the Gujarat High Court in Civil Revision Application No. 158 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 10, 1962 of the Gujarat High Court in Civil Revision Application No. 158 of 1960.

facts.text: Gujarat High Court confirmed the order of the District Judge, Kaira, holding that the 1st respondent was a debtor and directing the Civil Judge, Kapadvanj, to adjust the debt under the Bombay Agricultural Debtors Relief Act.

anchor.surface_text: confirming that of the District Judge, Kaira, holding that the 1st respondent herein was a debtor and directing the Civil Judge, Kapadvanj, to adjust the debt under the provisions of the Bombay Agricultural Debtors Relief Act.

facts.text: Father of the first respondent owned three pieces of land bearing Survey Nos. 93, 102/3 and 125/1 in village Chikhlod, Taluka Kapadvanj, District Kaira in the State of Gujarat.

anchor.surface_text: The father of the first respondent owned three pieces of land bearing Survey Nos. 93, 102/3 and 125/1 in village Chikhlod, Taluka Kapadvanj, District Kaira in the State of Gujarat.

facts.text: On June 9, 1933, father of first respondent sold the lands by an oral vardi to respondent No. 2 for Rs. 2,701 but continued to be in possession thereof.

anchor.surface_text: On June 9, 1933, he sold the same by an oral vardi to respondent No. 2 for a sum of Rs. 2,701 but continued to be in possession thereof.

facts.text: On April 7, 1934, the 2nd respondent sold the said lands to the 1st appellant by an oral vardi for Rs. 2,521 and the 1st appellant got possession thereof on the said date.

anchor.surface_text: On April 7, 1934, the 2nd respondent sold the said lands to the 1st appellant by an oral vardi for Rs. 2,521 and the 1st appellant got possession thereof on the said date.

facts.text: In a partition in the joint family of the 1st appellant, survey No. 93 went to the share of the 2nd appellant and the remaining two lands to the 1st appellant.

anchor.surface_text: In a partition that was effected in the joint family of the 1st appellant, survey No. 93 went to the share of the 2nd appellant and the remaining two lands fell to the share of the 1st appellant.

facts.text: Appellants have been in possession of the said lands from April 7, 1934.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants have been in possession of the said lands from April 7, 1934.

facts.text: On August 3, 1945, the 1st respondent filed an application before the Debt Adjustment Board under s. 17, read with s. 18 and s. 45 of the Bombay Agricultural Debtors Relief Act, 1939. Only the 2nd respondent was made a party.

anchor.surface_text: On August 3, 1945, the 1st respondent filed an application before the Debt Adjustment Board under s. 17, read with s. 18 and s. 45 of the Bombay Agricultural Debtors Relief Act, 1939. To that application only the 2nd respondent was made a party.

facts.text: 1st respondent claimed his father had money dealings with the 2nd respondent and sold lands in 1933 by oral sale with condition of reconveyance, debt liable to adjustment.

anchor.surface_text: His case was that his father had money dealings with the 2nd respondent and in consideration of past debts his father had sold the said lands to the 2nd respondent in 1933 by way of an oral sale with a condition of reconveyance of the said lands to the vendor and, therefore, the said debt was liable to be adjusted under the provisions of the said Act.

facts.text: 2nd respondent denied money dealings with father of 1st respondent and stated lands were not in his possession.

anchor.surface_text: The 2nd respondent denied that he had any money dealings with the father of the 1st respondent and stated that the lands were not in his possession.

facts.text: On December 4, 1945, 1st respondent applied to add appellants as respondents; only 1st appellant added.

anchor.surface_text: On December 4, 1945, the respondent made an application before the Debt Adjustment Board for adding the appellants as respondents to the petition. It appears from the record that only the 1st appellant was made a party-respondent to that application.

facts.text: On April 29, 1947, Debt Adjustment Board held sales invalid and directed 2nd respondent to render accounts.

anchor.surface_text: On April 29, 1947, the said Board held that the sales in favour of the 2nd respondent and the appellants were invalid and directed the 2nd respondent to render the accounts.

facts.text: 2nd respondent appealed to District Judge at Nadiad against Board order.

anchor.surface_text: Against that order, the 2nd respondent preferred an appeal to the District Judge at Nadiad.

facts.text: Bombay Agricultural Debtors Relief Act 28 of 1947 came into force on May 27, 1947, repealing the 1939 Act.

anchor.surface_text: On May 27, 1947, Bombay Agricultural Debtors Relief Act 28 of 1947, hereinafter called the new Act, came into force and under s. 56 (2) thereof the Bombay Agricultural Debtors Relief Act, 1939, hereinafter called the repealed Act was repealed.

facts.text: On April 14, 1949, District Judge, Kaira set aside Board order and remanded to Civil Judge Junior Division at Kapadvanj to decide nature of transaction.

anchor.surface_text: On April 14, 1949 the learned District Judge, Kaira, set aside the order of the Board and remanded the case to the court of the Civil Judge Junior Division at Kapadvanj with a direction to decide afresh the question of the nature of the said transaction in accordance with law.

facts.text: On April 24, 1950, 1st respondent applied to add 2nd appellant as party, allowed on August 21, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On April 24, 1950, the 1st respondent made an application before the Civil Judge for adding the 2nd appellant as a party respondent and that petition was allowed on August 21, 1950.

facts.text: On September 29, 1953, Civil Judge dismissed the petition as not maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: On September 29, 1953, the Civil Judge dismissed the petition as not maintainable

facts.text: District Judge, Kaira allowed appeal against Civil Judge's dismissal and remanded.

anchor.surface_text: but on appeal the District Judge, Kaira, allowed the appeal and remanded the matter to the Civil Judge for disposal according to law.

facts.text: Appellants and 2nd respondent's revision to High Court summarily rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants and the 2nd respondent preferred a revision to the High Court, but that was summarily rejected.

facts.text: After remand, Civil Judge held transaction not a mortgage and appellants acquired title by adverse possession.

anchor.surface_text: After the remand, the Civil Judge held that the transaction was not a mortgage and the appellants had acquired title to the lands by adverse possession.

facts.text: District Judge on October 16, 1958 held mortgage subsisted, no title by adverse possession, remanded for debt adjustment.

anchor.surface_text: Against that order the 1st respondent preferred an appeal to the District Judge, who, by his order dated October 16, 1958, held that the mortgage subsisted and that the appellants had not acquired title to the said lands by adverse possession. In that view, he remanded the case to the Civil Judge for adjustment of the debts.

facts.text: Gujarat High Court accepted District Judge's finding and dismissed revision.

anchor.surface_text: On revision the High Court of Gujarat accepted the finding of the learned District Judge and dismissed the revision.

facts.text: Appellants in possession from April 7, 1934 to August 3, 1945, period less than 12 years.

anchor.surface_text: From April 7, 1934 to August 3, 1945 the appellants were in possession of the disputed lands and the said period of occupation of the lands by the appellants was less than 12 years.

facts.text: Appellants claimed 1st respondent was tenant from June 9, 1933 to April 7, 1934 to tack on to adverse possession period.

anchor.surface_text: But it was contended that the 1st respondent was in possession of the lands as a tenant of the 1st appellant between June 9, 1933 to April 7, 1934 and, therefore, the said period should be tacked on to the period of adverse possession by the appellants.

facts.text: High Court found, agreeing with District Judge, that appellants failed to prove 1st respondent was tenant during 1933-1934.

anchor.surface_text: But the High Court found, agreeing with the District Judge, that the appellants failed to prove that the 1st respondent was in possession of the lands as a tenant during that period.

facts.text: Father of 1st respondent in possession from June 9, 1933 to April 7, 1934.

anchor.surface_text: From June 9, 1933 to April 7, 1934 the father of the 1st respondent was in possession.

issues.text: Whether the Board and Civil Judge lacked jurisdiction to add the appellants as parties after the 18 months limitation period under s.17 of the repealed Bombay Agricultural Debtors Relief Act, 1939, rendering such orders void and creating vested rights in the appellants unaffected by the new Act of 1947?

anchor.surface_text: 1  Under the repealed Act the Board would have jurisdiction to entertain an application for adjustment of debts, if it was filed within 18 months from the date of the appointment of the Board under s. 4 of the said Act, i.c., on or before October 31, 1945, and, as nosuch application was filed either against the 1st appellant or against the 2nd appellant before that date, the order of the Board adding the 1st appellant on December 4, 1945, and the order of the Civil Judge adding the 2nd appellant on August 21, 1950 were without jurisdiction and, therefore, void as the said orders were without jurisdiction, the appellants had acquired a vested interest in the property and the new Act does no

issues.text: Whether the appellants had acquired title to the lands by adverse possession?

anchor.surface_text: 2  The appellant had acquired a right to the said lands by adverse possession. The application to the Board to investigate the nature of the transaction was not competent.

issues.text: Whether the application to the Board to investigate the nature of the transaction was competent?

anchor.surface_text: The application to the Board to investigate the nature of the transaction was not competent.

issues.text: Whether the benefit under s. 55(6)(b) of the Transfer of Property Act is available only to a buyer under a valid transaction and not to a buyer under a transaction which is void at the very inception?

anchor.surface_text: The benefit under s. 55 6 b  of the Transfer of Property Act is available only to a buyer under a valid transaction and not to a buyer under a transaction which is void at the very inception.

issues.text: Whether the provisos to s.56(2) of the Bombay Agricultural Debtors Relief Act, 1947, deem pending proceedings under the repealed Act to be proceedings under the new Act, attracting s.46 proviso for adding parties post time-limit?

anchor.surface_text: This proviso introduces a fiction and under that fiction, if an application filed before the Board under s. 17 of the repealed Act was pending at the time the new Act came into force, it shall be continued as if it were an application filed under s. 4 of the new Act.

issues.text: Whether the provisos to s.56(2) give retrospective effect to all provisions of the new Act, including substantive provisions, for pending proceedings?

anchor.surface_text: the language of the provisos to s. 56 2 of the new Act clearly gave retrospective effect to all the provisions of the new Act including the substantive provisions and not merely to the procedural provisions thereof.

arguments.claim: Under the repealed Act the Board would have jurisdiction to entertain an application for adjustment of debts only if filed within 18 months from the date of the appointment of the Board under s. 4, i.e., on or before October 31, 1945, and as no such application was filed against the appellants before that date, the orders adding them were without jurisdiction and void, creating vested interest unaffected by the new Act.

holdings.text: Pending proceedings under the repealed Act (Bombay Agricultural Debtors Relief Act, 1939) before the Debt Adjustment Board at the time the new Act (Bombay Agricultural Debtors Relief Act, 1947) came into force shall be continued and disposed of by the Court under the new Act as if an application under section 4 had been made to the Court.
holdings.reasoning_summary: First proviso to s.56(2) introduces statutory fiction deeming pending Board proceedings as applications under s.4 of new Act; follows textual interpretation and precedents like Vishwanath.

holdings.text: Pending appeals under the repealed Act shall be continued and disposed of as if they were appeals under the provisions of the new Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Third proviso to s.56(2) creates fiction applying new Act provisions to pending appeals; consistent with overall scheme for continuity.

holdings.text: The provisos to s.56(2) of the new Act give retrospective effect to all provisions of the new Act, including substantive provisions, not merely procedural provisions, for pending proceedings under the repealed Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Language of provisos requires treating pending matters under new Act fully; accords with Bombay High Court precedents (Vishwanath, Hiraman, Basavanappa).

holdings.text: Under s.46 proviso of the new Act, the Court may add or strike out parties under Order 1 Rule 10 CPC in proceedings under s.4 even after the specified time limit has elapsed.

anchor.surface_text: Section 46. Save as otherwise expressly provided in this Act, the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, shall apply to all proceedings under this Chapter. Provided that the Court may in a proper case and on such terms as may appear to it to be just, exercise its powers to add or strike out parties under rule 10 of Order 1 of the said Code

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.46 proviso empowering post-limitation addition of parties; applies to deemed proceedings under new Act.

holdings.text: The Debt Adjustment Board and Civil Judge had jurisdiction to add the appellants as parties after the limitation period under s.17 of the repealed Act; orders adding 1st appellant on Dec 4, 1945 and 2nd appellant on Aug 21, 1950 were valid; no vested rights acquired by appellants unaffected by new Act.

anchor.surface_text: As the appeal against the order of the Board was pending at the time the new Act came into force, under proviso  c  to s. 56 2  of the new Act that appeal had to be disposed of under the provisions of the new Act and after remand the application had likewise to be disposed of under the provisions of the new Act. At that time the civil Court had ample jurisdiction to add the appellants as parties irrespective of the time limit prescribed under the repealed Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application pending under repealed Act deemed under new Act via s.56(2) provisos; s.46 proviso allows post-time addition; rejects petitioner's limitation/jurisdiction argument.

holdings.text: The appellants did not acquire title to the lands by adverse possession.

anchor.surface_text: Against that order the 1st respondent preferred an appeal to the District Judge, who, by his order dated October 16, 1958, held that the mortgage subsisted and that the appellants had not acquired title to the said lands by adverse possession. In that view, he remanded the case to the Civil Judge for adjustment of the debts. On revision the High Court of Gujarat accepted the finding of the learned District Judge and dismissed the revision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supreme Court accepts District Judge/High Court concurrent findings: possession from Apr 7, 1934 to Aug 3, 1945 <12 years; failed to prove tacking via tenancy 1933-34.

holdings.text: The transaction was a mortgage that subsisted; debt liable to adjustment under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: On revision the High Court of Gujarat accepted the finding of the learned District Judge and dismissed the revision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts lower courts' findings on nature of transaction as mortgage (not sale); appellants' possession permissive/not adverse.

holdings.text: New points (3rd and 4th contentions) not raised before High Court cannot be raised before Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: At the outset it may be mentioned that the 4th point was sought to be raised before the High Court for the first time and the High Court refused to go into that matter. We cannot, therefore, allow the appellants to raise that point before us. The third point was also not raised before the High Court and we do not see any justification for allowing the appellants to press the same before us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural bar: points not urged below; no justification to entertain in appeal.

precedents.citation: Vishwanath Mahadev Adhikari v. Krishnaji Ramchandra Bodas 1

anchor.surface_text: Vishwanath Mahadev Adhikari v. Krishnaji Ramchandra Bodas 1

precedents.case_name: Vishwanath Mahadev Adhikari v. Krishnaji Ramchandra Bodas
precedents.cited_proposition: scope of the three provisos to s. 56(2) of the new Act; provisos have retrospective effect making pending appeals to be continued and disposed of as if under the new Act applying all its provisions substantive and procedural
precedents.cited_holding: Further, in our opinion, the language used in proviso 2 is fairly clear and explicit and makes this proviso retrospective in its effect. What the Legislature says is that the appeals shall be continued and disposed of as if they were appeals under this Act, which clearly means that all the provisions of this Act shall apply to the appeals which are pending. The appeal Court is asked to treat the appeals as if the new Act was in force and not the old Act, and in disposing of those appeals the appeal Court has to consider the substantive law as well as the procedural law brought into force by Act XXVIII of 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Section 46. Save as otherwise expressly provided in this Act, the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, shall apply to all proceedings under this Chapter. Provided that the Court may in a proper case and on such terms as may appear to it to be just, exercise its powers to add or strike out parties under rule 10 of Order 1 of the said Code
As the appeal against the order of the Board was pending at the time the new Act came into force, under proviso  c  to s. 56 2  of the new Act that ap

anchor.surface_text: As the appeal against the order of the Board was pending at the time the new Act came into force, under proviso  c  to s. 56 2  of the new Act that appeal had to be disposed of under the provisions of the new Act and after remand the application had likewise to be disposed of under the provisions of the new Act. At that time the civil Court had ample jurisdiction to add the appellants as parties irrespective of the time limit prescribed under the repealed Act.

As the appeal against the order of the Board was pending at the time the new Act came into force, under proviso  c  to s. 56 2  of the new Act that appeal had to be disposed of under the provisions of the new Act and after remand the application had likewise to be disposed of under the provisions of the new Act. At that time the civil Court had ample jurisdiction to add the appellants as parties irrespective of the time limit prescribed under the repealed Act.

edges.explanation: Holding that no title by adverse possession directly resolves the issue.

anchor.surface_text: Against that order the 1st respondent preferred an appeal to the District Judge, who, by his order dated October 16, 1958, held that the mortgage subsisted and that the appellants had not acquired title to the said lands by adverse possession. In that view, he remanded the case to the Civil Judge for adjustment of the debts. On revision the High Court of Gujarat accepted the finding of the learned District Judge and dismissed the revision.

Against that order the 1st respondent preferred an appeal to the District Judge, who, by his order dated October 16, 1958, held that the mortgage subsisted and that the appellants had not acquired title to the said lands by adverse possession. In that view, he remanded the case to the Civil Judge for adjustment of the debts. On revision the High Court of Gujarat accepted the finding of the learned District Judge and dismissed the revision.
On revision the High Court of Gujarat accepted the finding of the learned District Judge and dismissed the revision.

At the outset it may be mentioned that the 4th point was sought to be raised before the High Court for the first time and the High Court refused to go into that matter. We cannot, therefore, allow the appellants to raise that point before us. The third point was also not raised before the High Court and we do not see any justification for allowing the appellants to press the same before us.
